Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: They must follow strict procedures for a large cash deposit at the end of a busy shift to comply with corporate auditing rules.
Story:
I glanced at the clock above the register, my heart pounding as the minutes ticked closer to seven. My phone buzzed in my pocket—another message from my sister, reminding me that everyone was waiting for me at the family dinner. Mom had made my favorite, and Dad rarely asked for all of us to be together. I could almost hear their laughter through the phone, the clinking of dishes, the warmth I’d been missing.

But the line at the store was still long, and my manager had just handed me the deposit bag. “You know the rules,” she said. “Every bill counted, every form signed. No shortcuts.” The procedures were strict, and if I made a mistake, it could mean a write-up or worse. I felt the weight of responsibility pressing down on me—my family expecting me to show up, to be present, to be a good brother; my job demanding precision, patience, and adherence to every policy.

I stood there, torn, the deposit bag heavy in my hands, my phone buzzing again. I could feel the pull from both sides, each expectation stretching me thin, and I didn’t know which part of me I could let down.
